headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Michigan School Shooter's Mom Testifies In Her Own Defense. Aired 2:30-3p ET

utterances.speaker: JENNIFER CRUMBLEY, DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: And then when I'm back to the fire station, then I won't have a signal. And then I had hit the grocery store, I have a signal. Once I get back to the grocery, all the way to the barn, I had no signal.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON SMITH, DEFENSE ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Looking back on these texts now from March 9th, seeing him say there's someone in the house that day, someone locked in the bathroom, they the light on, do you think he was having mental issues that day?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What do you think -- what was your conclusion about these messages at that time?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He was just messing with us.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Is this the kind of "messing" you previously talked about?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: All right, I want to go to March 20th. This is People's Exhibits 96 through 100. They established -- let me see, this is you, yes?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. And another picture of you.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And we've got data showing that you are out there, correct?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And there's a text message exchange that was admitted as People's 96, and we'll put that up on the screen for you, OK?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: In People's 96, this is between you and your son, correct?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct. SMITHyour dad, text me when you're done. Done yet?" And he starts up with, "I just -- I finished picking up the room. I cleaned until clothes started flying off the shelf. This stuff only happens when I'm home alone. I picked the clothes back up though." That's at, it looks like 2:34. And we may be off by an hour so because of UTC. This one's minus four. Your next text is, "Jumping in the shower, text your dad if I don't respond." And your text, no matter what the time zone is, is six hours later. Do you recall getting these text messages?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It's two days in six hours later.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, you're right. Two days and six hours.So do you recall getting these couple on the 20th about, "I finished picking up the room. I cleaned until clothes started falling off the shelf. Do you recall that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Only when we got discovery.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Looking back on these dates, are you thinking, oh, my god, there were -- he thought things were happening that were crazy?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Do you think anything of it now?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What do you think is happening in those messages?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I just think he was messing with us.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Those are three times where you guys are at the ranch and he's messing with you, is that a fair statement?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: At that time, that was months and months before November. It was in March, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Beyond March, was there other times where he was saying these goofy texts and messing around?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So there's two more dates I need to ask you about. I'm going to go to April 4th, which was a Sunday. And that is going to be Exhibit, that was admitted one-on-one, OK?So Exhibit 101 are text messages, and these are between -- who are these between?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Those were between my son and his friend.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Prior to this case, did you ever see any of these messages?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I did not.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Were you aware any of them existed?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I was not.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: This is from April 4th and your son is saying -- sending messages that say, "I hear people talking to me and some in the distance. I actually asked my dad to take me to the doctor yesterday but he gave me some pills and told me to suck it up. It's at the point, I'm asking to go to the doctor."Was there ever a time where he asked to go to the doctor around this time?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't think so, no.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Then he says, "My mom laughed when I told her."Was there ever a time where he was asking for help and you are laughing?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: He writes to his friends -- and this is just later that night -- but, "I'm having bad insomnia and paranoia. I need help. I was thinking of calling 9-1-1 so I could go to the hospital, but then my parents would be really pissed."OK, this is all one long conversation, is that right?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: He says, "I'm going to ask my parents to go to the doctors tomorrow or Tuesday again, but this time I'm going to tell them about the voices."This text message or Instant Message thread, did you ever -- were you even aware of this?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No. SMITHto go to a doctor or to get help and you said no --

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: -- or laughed at him?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So when you see these texts with his friend, do you have any idea -- and if you don't that's fine. Do you have any idea what he's doing with his friend?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't have any idea.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Do you know if he and his friend messed around with each other like you and your husband do?

utterances.speaker: MARK KEAST, ASSISTANT OAKLAND COUNTY PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: Speculation, Judge.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: CHERYL MATTHEWS, OAKLAND COUNTY CIRCUIT JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Sustained.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: When you were testifying earlier today --

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: All right, we're listening to testimony from Jennifer Crumbley, the mother of the Oxford High School shooter. That fatal shooting taking the lives of four students back in 2021, there in Michigan.Let's listen in as she's talking about sort of the state of mind of her son in the months leading up to the shooting.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you do anything to hurt in appearance when his friend was taken away, essentially, to the hospital, or to the other school? CRUMBLEY

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you do anything different as a parent in terms of spending time with your son?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I mean, we did as much as we could.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Tell us about that. Tell us about that month.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: We did more family game nights than normal. He was working a lot. I would check in with him and make sure he was doing OK.That's why I started asking him to have friends at school that you can hang out with, and if so, you're more than welcome to invite them over.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I was more pointing to the fact that he was sad.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Even though he was sad, did you feel like there is anything where he needed help or needed mental health treatment?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Was the loss of his friend being in his life anything that made you think he needed counseling or a therapist?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Not to that extent, no.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And I'm going to unplug this so we can go to some questions that don't involve this. OK?OK. So we were talking earlier about the mother-son gun range day, right? You've already told the jury how the gun was put in the car and taken out. Now did you ever tell Brian Maloney about the mother-son day at the range?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I'm sure I mentioned it, yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you ever tell Brian that the gun was in your vehicle?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: When did you tell Brian that the gun was in your vehicle?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: On the day I went to the shooting range.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you tell Brian you put the gun in your car the day the shooting happened?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No. SMITH

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No, I think he was confused.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Did you specifically tell him about the gun being put in your car that other time?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Aside from that time that you drove to the range, was the gun ever in your car?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Were you aware Brian had memory issues?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No, I was not.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Brian testified that he never met Ethan. Later in his testimony, he said that he did. Did he ever meet Ethan?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, a couple times at the barn.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: And we went -- he came to our house, helped deliver a big TV that we got and my son was there.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you ever tell Brian anything about your son seeing things or making you upset in any way like that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you ever tell Brian anything about he had mental health issues that you are worried about?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So when we read your messages, which the prosecution admitted 77 pages, OK, it's fair to say the jury can read what you guys talked about, and you reflect on, all -- you talk about the past with Ethan, correct?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So the jury can read those. We don't need to go through those, you agree?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. We've got to Monday. Monday's two days after you guys go to the mother-son day at the shooting range. Monday, responded to the voice mail. We talked about that already, talked about you talking to your son about it, right?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Do you remember Tuesday the 30th?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: That day, you saw an exhibit when you going into work. Did that happen?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And you gave testimony already about you getting a call from Shawn (ph) Hopkins?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct. He left me a voice mail. I called him back.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. When you called back, Mr. Hopkins testified that he sent you something. What did he send you.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: He sent me a copy of a math worksheet that had scribbled-out drawings on it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I want to ask you, the night before that scribbled-out drawing thing came to you, did you have any interactions with your son?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, we did.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What were those about?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I saw on Power School that he got a D in geometry, so we got into an argument again about his grades. We took his phone away and told him that he couldn't go to the shooting range until his grades were brought back up.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. So you guys had this argument the night before. And we saw lots of messages where you thought everything was fine that Tuesday morning. Is that how you felt?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. When you got that math paper texted to you, do you recall saying anything to Ethan on the phone, on speaker?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I asked him why he -- why he did that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. What were you thinking at that point?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I was actually kind of angry because I thought he was -- he did that in like defiance of us yelling at him about missing assignments, and here he is drawing pictures on an empty assignment page in geometry.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: So you felt he was specifically he was sending you a message about the night before?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Is it fair to say you took a personally?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What did you do?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I had asked Mr. Hopkins to -- if you have the original, and then he sent it to my email, which then I opened up and looked at it and was like OK.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What did you think when you saw that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I was a little concerned. I was pretty concerned. He had asked for a parent to come to the school to meet with them. And at this time, I tried calling my husband to see if he could go, because he was out in the area working and I couldn't get a hold of him.So I decided to go to school. On the way to the school, he finally called me back and he met me at the school, so we went together.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. When you went into the school, what did you think was happening?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I thought he was going to get in trouble for what he drew on his assignment. I thought he was going to get suspended. I was expecting a disciplinary meeting.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: How did you feel about what you saw on the paper?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I felt concerned after seeing that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. We saw that you sent pictures of the math paper to Kyra, to Andy, to Brian. It's fair to say that you sent them around to people.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: And to all those people -- we've already seen these exhibits -- you expressed that concern?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: What happens when you get to the school? And you and James are separate, the detective testified he was wrong at first thinking you guys went together. You guys were separate. But you got there at the same time.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Went in. What was it like walking into the meeting with Mr. Hopkins and Mr. (INAUDIBLE), who was there?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: When we first got there, Mr. Hopkins met us out in front of where the administration is and walked us back to his counseling office.When we walked in, it was just him and then my son was sitting in a chair in front of his desk, working on something on his laptop. When we walked in, he kind of showed us where to sit and then we shook hands, he introduced himself, and we started the meeting.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you try to hug Ethan or do anything like that?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I didn't.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. How did that meeting go?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you feel like you were in the position of, I am leaving him in the school whether he could be here or not.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No, absolutely not.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Were you surprised or were you not surprised? Did you have any feelings about whether or not he could have stayed in school?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I thought the advice they were giving us was good advice. We talked about him being sad, and then he said being around peers usually helps. We all agreed to that.My son was very stressed out in the virtual school. So we agreed that might stress him out more to do his school remotely the rest of the day. But there was never a time where I would refuse to take him home. I could easily, if he wanted to go, take him with me. I had no issues with that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Ultimately, did you take the paper from the school?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: The counseling papers, yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: There was a stack, 10 sheets, with multiple counselors listed on them.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Were you planning to do anything with that sheet?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, we were going to start -- I gave it to my husband in the parking lot and I told him -- actually, I had phone calls at work the rest of the day. I told him to start making calls once he got done doing his Door Dash.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. The prosecution introduced and admitted an exhibit which was a search off of Yahoo about clinical depression treatments. Do you recall ever -- I'm saying Googling, but do you recall ever searching that topic?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't. I don't usually use Yahoo as a search engine. I use Google. I don't know -- I don't recall it. No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. Do you recall how or if you ever saw anything on Yahoo about legal clinical depression?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't remember specifically seeing anything. I might have looked at something when my husband was going through a hard time after his mother passed away. He was drinking a little bit more than usual and he wasn't right.I may have looked at something at that time, seeing if he was depressed. But I don't know where Yahoo came from.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: You don't know where Yahoo came from?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. When you are on Facebook and Instagram and all those things, do you ever hit the click-bait stuff?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: Sometimes on accident. Sometimes I do on purpose.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. That search on Yahoo, you don't remember ever putting that in the search bar?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. But you are saying it is possible you looked at it?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It's possible.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. All right. So, let's go back. You are at the meeting. How did it end?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It was decided that Ethan was -- my son was going to go back to his class. After he left, all four of us were in the meeting and they asked if we had any questions and we did not.I said, I'm going to go back to work. And we left and I went to work and my husband did Door Dash.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Did you mean to be abrupt about ending the meeting?

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: I didn't think I was abrupt. SMITH

utterances.speaker: CRUMBLEY
utterances.sentences: It just automatically ended when they asked if I had any questions and I said no.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: OK. When there was testimony about that -- I'm sorry, Strike that. (INAUDIBLE)(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: We can do it now.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: All rise for the jury.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: All right, a critical moment there in the trial as Jennifer Crumbley was testifying there because, previously her boyfriend or the man she was having an affair with, she texted him saying she was worried that Ethan was going to do something dumb. She texted him that the morning of the shooting.And this is her talking about this meeting where she goes to the school. Clearly, they have some concerns. She certainly is aware her son has access to a gun. But ultimately, she does not take her son home, nor does her husband. They did not immediately search for mental health professionals. She said she was going to do that later.
